course.subject: COMP
course.name: Parallel Programming
course.description: Introduction to parallel computer architectures; principles of parallel algorithm design; shared-memory programming models; message passing programming models used for cluster computing; data-parallel programming models for GPUs; case studies of parallel algorithms, systems, and applications; hands-on experience with writing parallel programs for tasks of interest.

reviews.author: ABCDEFD
reviews.title: Course is fine but the grade is not good.
reviews.comment_content:
The course include MPI+OPENMP+CUDA+Pthread.

And focus on MPI+CUDA+Pthread.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Good.

Professor is patient and nice enough.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grade is tough.

For the assignment, if you will receive huge deduction if you fail one case. The grade is only depended on the final result.

And the mean is B+, meaning that for PhDs, if you are in the last 50% students, you will fail the course.
reviews.comment_workload:
Three assignments on MPI+CUDA+Pthread, respectively.

If you are not familiar with them,  these works will cost more than 1 day.

reviews.author: Zephyrus
reviews.title: This Course is Only Suitable for Students who are Proficient in C++ Programming
reviews.comment_content: The contents can be separated into four parts, including MPI (distributed memory programming), POSIX Threads & OpenMP (shared memory programming)  and CUDA. Each part has the corresponding homework and questions in the final exam.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching is pretty good, with clear slides and code demo. Prof. Luo is quite helpful and responsive.
reviews.comment_grading:
If you reach the average, you will get B+.

The grading is fair, and strict, with clear test cases and clear grading scheme. Therefore, no need to appeal.

HOWEVER, the gradings are quite HARSH for some TA!!!!!!!  If the TA think your programming does not satisfy his taste, he will give you ZERO points without any consideration. (although you can appeal in this case, it really disturb you anyway.)
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is fairly heavy for me, at least for whom are not familiar with C++ programming. Each homework can be done in approximately 3 days with less than 150 lines of codes and you will meet weird bugs during the programming.

reviews.author: Ups_and_Downs
reviews.comment_content: The content includes up-to-date parallel computing tools like CUDA. The lecturer also spent some time explaining the relevant computer architectures for better understanding. And I think some basic knowledge of computers and proficiency in C can help you learn this course more smoothly.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. LUO is really good at teaching, she explains much better than reading the slides by yourself. Also, 2 separate 80 mins courses in two days are not that stressful compared to 2 classes in a row.
reviews.comment_grading: I have trouble finishing the assignment in time which affects my grade, it seems that the lecture didn't adjust the grade and just convert to letter grades in five-point intervals. But I think the overall grading is fine.
reviews.comment_workload: For a student from the ECE department, I think the workload of coding is quite heavy because it's not easy to debug and tune parallel computing programming. It usually takes me around two days or more to finish the coding and I suggest you try to finish the job first rather than thinking about how to gain maximum performance at the very beginning of the 3 assignments

reviews.author: Dipsy
reviews.comment_content:
1. MPI (Across processesâ€‹, send shared data to processes explicitly)
2. Pthread (Across threads, use shared memory)
3. OpenMP (Pragmas, use shared memory)
4. CUDA (GPU programming)

Homework on 1,2,4

in my opinion, CUDA is the most difficult since GPU is a totally different architecture then CPU, making an efficient GPU program is more challenging

These are really useful tools in big data or software engineering, so quite worthy to learn
reviews.comment_teaching:
I know the instructor is a good teacher since I took her COMP3031 before, but I still skipped most lectures :)

The TAs are quite kind and will response your queries quite quick

Assignments are well designed
Serial version algorithm, skeleton code, and sample test cases of different sizes are given and we need to implement MPI, Pthread, and CUDA version, which is not difficult but really a proof of concept, no need to compete for the speed with classmates, just need to
1. output the correct answer as the serial version did
2. faster than serial in big data set
3. faster if more threads provided in big data set

The final has provided us all the required API and constants so we don't need to recite, only need a very abstract idea on how these API works to answer the concept questions
reviews.comment_grading:
50% PA, 50% final (10% concept short question, 40% programming)

the assignment and exam have high transparency, know all the test cases and model answers

the 40% programming exam is just fill in the blanks, no need to code from scratch

mean is B+ (I guess A+ will need 95%+, my score is around 93% which is A, so if you want A+ you need to be super careful which I didn't)
reviews.comment_workload:
Not high, each assignment can be done in around 100 lines of code.
The fastest one I can do it in 2 hours, the slowest one I do it in 2 days.
But each I spend a day setting up the environment on my own computer (which I can actually just use lab2 machines, but develop locally has faster dev cycle and after graduation, you can continue using them)
If you are very not used to parallel programming, you may need more time and longer code, every line of code would be blood and tears, tbh parallel programs are quite hard to debug

I only review on the day before the exam, and I seldom listen to lectures, I learn everything during coding the assignments, except OpenMP don't have PA, and it only has one question in the exam

reviews.author: tideline
reviews.comment_content: This course introdues parallel programming models and mainstream parallel programming interfaces including OpenMP, MPI, Pthreads and CUDA.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Luo teaches the concepts very well by clear explanations and detailed hands-on of example codes. She welcomes any problems on class and is willing to  discuss with you.
reviews.comment_grading: There are three programming assignments (50%) and a closed-book final exam (50%). The programming assignments require solving a problem using different parallel programming interfaces with skeleton codes given.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload of this course is light. If you can fully understand the parallel programming techniques, the programming assignments should not be hard to finish.

reviews.author: whatAreYou
reviews.title: Terrifying grading for CSE student
reviews.comment_content: The content is OK simple. Need proficiency in C++ otherwise it is really a nightmare. Learn some tools in parallel programming. And learn some algorithms in the assignment, which may be useful for a job interview.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Luo's teaching is OK. The content is easy to understand by itself.
reviews.comment_grading: Bad, Less than half of the class get B+. The grading curve is terrible and not reasonable for a core CSE pg course. The final exam is critical and you need to be good at it.
reviews.comment_workload: Heavy. 4 projects which are totally different every year. And the key to solving the assignment is about learning the algorithm of the project, instead of practicing the use of parallel programming skills.

reviews.author: An zhu Yeung
reviews.title: Well established and interesting course, quite easy-going
reviews.comment_content: Content is almost similar each year. Overall is interesting and useful in understanding parallel programming paradigms and methods.Unfortunately, not much of GPU parallel programming, but CUDA is included and 1 of 3 assignments is about GPU programming.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Excellent orals and lecture presentations. Detailed tutorial descriptions.
Instructor and TAs are accessible to ask for any help about tutorial and course content.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is fare and had no need to be appealed.
reviews.comment_workload:
3 assignments: mild difficulty, every assignment can be done in 2-3 days of experimenting with code. Tasks sometimes imply creativity, to use some of tricks, proposed on lectures, but also hidden from student.
Final Exam is about knowledge of coding in 3 different languages/paradigms included in lectures. Generally speaking tasks on Finals are easy/medium difficulty.

reviews.author: sycamore
reviews.comment_content: The content is a very good and wide range. It covers a whole bunch of topic of parallel computing.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching is excellent and excellent and excellent and excellent. The professor is well-experienced and teaches very carefully with numerous enthusiasm.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is very very perfect. Everyone got an A. I don't like the professor, however, he gave everyone an A. I want the curve.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is not heavy. I felt it is a fucking easy and light-loaded course and this is the simplest course I have taken.

reviews.author: Neige(that)
reviews.title: This course is shit
reviews.comment_content:
A lot of information. Very hard to learn them all.
The course is about MPI, multi-process, and CUDA. There are many case studies and detail analyses. All those cases and analyses may exist in the final exam, so there is a lot of information to review.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Luo just reads her slides word by word. Prof. Luo may also be not familiar with slides and hesitate about the slide's content.
reviews.comment_grading: Very strict. Many students get B. My friend got a B+. My assignment is a full mark, and my final exam is very high. I am sure my score is in the top three. However, I only get an A instead of an A+. Do not choose it.
reviews.comment_workload: 3 parallel programming homework, including multi-process, multi-thread, and CUDA
